description: Modus Ponens is one of the most fundamental inference rules in logic. It states: if we have a conditional statement (if P then Q) and we know P is true, we can conclude Q is true.

problems.solution: Apply Modus Ponens directly: from "P implies Q" and "P", we conclude "Q".
Apply Modus Ponens: from "R implies S" and "R", we conclude "S".
Direct application of Modus Ponens with variables A and B.
Apply Modus Ponens where the antecedent is a conjunction "P ∧ Q".
Apply Modus Ponens: the consequent is a conjunction, so we get "Q ∧ R".
Apply Modus Ponens where the antecedent is a disjunction.
First apply Modus Ponens to get "Q → R", then apply it again with "Q" to get "R".
Use Conjunction to combine P and Q into "P ∧ Q", then apply Modus Ponens.
Apply Hypothetical Syllogism to get "P → R", then use Modus Ponens with P.
Apply Double Negation on P to get "¬¬P", then Modus Ponens to get Q, construct "P → Q", finally Modus Ponens to get R.
